programme.title: I Was There
programme.desc: A deadly nerve agent is released in Salisbury. Former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia are both poisoned. An innocent member of the community, Dawn Sturgess, died. After an inquiry looked into the events of 2018 and what happened to Dawn Sturgess. We hear from those who were on the ground and at the centre of the story.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: Jeremy Vine joins The Media Show to discuss his recent court victories over Joey Barton, the former footballer who earlier this month received a suspended prison sentence for offensive social media posts. The case has raised questions about where criticism ends and criminal conduct begins. The mass shooting at Bondi Beach during a Hanukkah event created major challenges for journalists trying to confirm fast-moving details. Newsrooms had to decide how to describe the attack, when to name suspects, and how to treat unverified online posts. Jacqueline Maley, senior writer at the Sydney Morning Herald, explains the decisions behind early reporting and the influence of social media. In Florida, Donald Trump has filed a defamation case against the BBC over an edited sequence in the Panorama documentary, which triggered the resignation of the corporation's Director General and its CEO of News. Stuart M Benjamin, professor of law at Duke University, sets out the legal issues.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: The Travel Show
programme.desc: Rob Bell is on an adventure through Norway's western fjords to explore the country's efforts to protect this landscape for future generations. In Geiranger, a UNESCO World Heritage site, he meets the dedicated scientists monitoring the monumental crevasse in Arknes mountain which threatens to collapse within the next 200 years. He climbs Europe's highest sea cliff, one of ten new National Parks the country's creating, and takes a home-grown electric car prototype for a spin.

programme.title: Global Women
programme.desc: Greenlandic parents across Denmark are fighting to be reunited with their children, who were taken into care after authorities used 'parenting competency tests' as part of assessments to judge their ability to raise them. After banning the tests for use on Greenlandic people, the Danish government has now pledged to review around 300 child removals, but not everyone's cases are being looked at.

programme.title: Ukrainecast
programme.desc: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky has welcomed an EU agreement to supply Kyiv with a €90bn loan, avoiding an imminent deficit in its wartime finances. It comes after Vladimir Putin referred to European leaders as "piglets" while dismissing any peace deal which does not "unconditionally" satisfy Russia's pre-invasion aims. The Russian president is yet to be presented with the latest US-led proposal on how to end the war in Ukraine, after Donald Trump spoke positively about progress made during multilateral talks in Berlin. To answer your questions, Lucy Hockings is joined in the Ukrainecast studio by the BBC's chief international correspondent Lyse Doucet, security correspondent Frank Gardner, and Europe digital editor Paul Kirby. Which competing visions are at play inside the White House as the US ramps up peace efforts? How is the Ukrainian air force being revolutionised? And could anything make China speak up on behalf of Ukraine?

programme.title: AI Decoded
programme.desc: The AI Decoded team explores the fight to protect artists from having their work mined by AI without consent. After a major UK government consultation, the message is clear: almost all respondents want stronger copyright protections and mandatory licensing for music, books, films, and more. Meanwhile virtually no respondents backed the government's original tech-friendly plan to let companies use creative works unless artists opt out. With the stakes high and the debate heating up, this episode dives into the clash between technology and artistry-and what it means for the future of creativity.
